data.message:
What's up everyone!
Presenting MATH.CODE.REPEAT., a month-long event that'll help you get better at math and coding at the same time.

Here are the rules:-
1) Partcipate in ProjectEuler+ on Hackerrank. Follow the link: https://www.hackerrank.com/contests/projecteuler/challenges
2) Solve a certain number of problems on or before midnight of Tuesday, 26th December 2017.
3) Get Free T-shirts! (Only for IITI students)
Yep. It's that easy!

The number of problems depends on the year you are in, and are as follows:-
1st Year - 50
2nd Year - 75
3rd Year - 100
4th Year - 125
(Once you start, it starts getting easy.)

We'll soon set up leaderboards and start accepting details of your submissions. For now, just keep a record of your problem and submission id's, and preserve the codes in a separate folder as well. We'll inform you about all the submission details in a subsequent post. Till then, enjoy crunching some equations. 

Hack away! :)

So finally ACM ICPC results are out for all the sites. Total 42 teams participated from IIT Indore. 

5 teams have been selected for the onsite regionals :

1. Heisenberg's LastVow : Apoorv Kulshrestha Aakash Handa Shubham Goyal (Rank 8) - Amritapuri and KGP
2. StayHigh : Vineet Shah Aditya Jain Gvs Akhil (Rank 38) - Chennai and Gwalior
3. Reverie : Kumar Abhinav Shashank Giri Shivam Tayal (Rank 59) - Kolkata and Amritapuri
4. oTo : Ashutosh Bang Daanish Mahajan Pushpendra Kumar (Rank 106) - Chennai and Amritapuri
5. strikhedonia : Rohit Ranjan Tapish Pratap Singh Akash Kamat (Rank 152) - Chennai

Congrats to all the qualified teams and we wish them luck for the onsite round!

#BrainTeaser1
#ZIUQ
 
Consider an input vector A[0,…,(2^n)-1] of integers from 0 to (2^n)-1. Now, this vector undergoes n operations. At a particular operation k(0<=k<n), the vector is divided into 2^k equal-sized small sub-vectors. Then this operation is performed: All the numbers lying at even positions are positioned first followed by numbers at odd positions while maintaining the order of the sequences.     
 (All positions are zero-based (e.g. 0 1 2 3…)).
He asks q queries, given the number S find its position in the final, shuffled sequence.

Sample example:

Suppose, we have N = 3. Therefore, we have a deck of 8 cards.
The shuffling is done in three steps:
Operation 1 k=0: We divide {0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7} in 2^0 decks. We get only one deck.
     Finally { 0, 2, 4, 6, 1, 3, 5, 7}.
Operation 2 k=1: We divide { 0, 2, 4, 6, 1, 3, 5, 7} in 2^1 decks. We get two decks: {0, 2, 4, 6} and {1, 3, 5, 7}. {0, 2, 4, 6} is reordered into {0, 4, 2, 6}, {1, 3, 5, 7} is reordered into {1, 5, 3, 7}.
We get { 0,4,2,6,1,5,3,7} finally.
Operation 3 k=2: We divide { 0,4,2,6,1,5,3,7} in 2^2 decks. We get four pairs: , {0, 4},{2, 6},{1, 5} and {3, 7}.
Nothing is changed in this step. We get the final, shuffled deck: { 0,4,2,6,1,5,3,7}
The card labelled 4 is in position 1.
The card labelled 3 is in position 6.
The card labelled 2 is in position 2.
Hint: Watch for the title.
Values for N and S are: 

N S
3  4
7 67
8 100

--OPTIONAL--
If you want to code in any programming language, feel free to share it on the form.
INPUT
The first line of input contains one number Q, the no of queries, Q lines follow. Each line contains two integers N and S, separated by a space.
OUTPUT
For each input, output a single integer, answer for the query
EXAMPLE:-
INPUT
3
3 4
3 3
3 2
OUTPUT
1
6
2

Submit here:
https://goo.gl/forms/Erh60pWDwhqCF6333

data.message:
Today is a big day for us. We are launching our new website, and will be hosting it on our own domain soon !
You will find weekly challenges, projects and informative blogs there. We'll be posting new challenges each weekend and their solutions after one-two weeks.
Good amount of management and efforts have gone into developing the website. We acknowledge the hard work put in by Kanishkar to design it.

So head on there and participate, we hope that you will learn something new from time to time.

P.S. - If you wish to suggest improvements, we would love to hear them !

data.message:
It's less than 12 hours remaining for Code Eve. We have added more problems so that you'll have more fun solving them. So brace up your skills and start practising. There are prizes for the top 3 overall performers as well. 

Contest Link: https://www.hackerrank.com/code-eve

Time: 
Monday 11 Sept 10:00pm - Tuesday 12 Sept 10:00pm

See you guys on the leaderboard!

After multiple requests from many people, we have decided to keep prizes for the top 3 overall performers (except IITI people). In case of overlaps between prizes, the next eligible candidate will get the prize.

What are you waiting for? Grab your keyboards now and start practising. Hope to see a lot of ACs. 

May the code be with you!

The contest link is :
https://www.hackerrank.com/code-eve

Schedule for the event is:
Mode : Online
Date : 11/09/2017, Wednesday - 12/09/2017, Thursday
Time : 10:00p.m. to 10:00p.m.

Hey folks,
We are starting off with our first contest - Code Eve.
This will be an online 24hr long contest for beginner to intermediate level competitive programmers .

The questions in Code Eve will mostly be analytical and mathematical. Anyone with a little programming experience can step up and have fun solving them. We have taken into account the participating first years and have tried to make the questions easy enough for you to attempt and learn. We have tried to make each question on a different concept so that you will be able to learn new things after the contest ends.

There will be a total of 11 problems in the contest. The problem setters are Gvs Akhil, Kumar Abhinav, Daanish Mahajan, Ashutosh Bang, Mohit Nathrani and Priyanshu Varshney Hope you'll like the problems and have fun solving them. 

There will be prizes for :
3 top performers from B.Tech 1st year
3 top performers from B.Tech 2nd year
2 top performers from rest of the students
(Prizes limited to only IITI students)

The contest link is :
https://www.hackerrank.com/code-eve

Schedule for the event is:
Mode : Online
Date   : 11/09/2017, Monday - 12/09/2017, Tuesday
Time  : 10:00p.m. to 10:00p.m.

Happy Coding!
Team Programming Club.

And with the new term, we take a look back upon the glorious moments of last year.

Team Divide by Zero 2016.

Hi folks! Third installment of our OWP series is here. This one develops an inventory management application in Java. It uses Swing API to make the GUI and MySQL for database. It also adds a print functionality to print receipts of withdraw. You can check it out at https://github.com/DaemonLab/OWP_Java_Inventory_Manager
.
The tutorial contains a pdf which explains properly how to navigate it and make the best use of this tutorial. Feel free to drop any suggestions (either on existing OWPs or about ideas for upcoming OWPs) either here or on github. :)
data.name: DaemonLab/OWP_Java_Inventory_Manager

data.message:
Continuing with our One Week Projects (OWP) series, our second tutorial is complete too, It is based on using FLTK GUI library in C++ to create a decent Image Viewer application. You can find it at: https://github.com/DaemonLab/OWP_Image_Viewer

Also, to make it easier for people to go through the tutorials, we have added a guide on how to navigate the tutorial. It can be found on the tutorial page as a pdf. This pdf is aimed for those people who don't have any experience with git. The guide is self contained and provides enough commands to work with the tutorials.
We have added a similar guide in our previous tutorial too.
Hopefully this will allow more people to join and enjoy the OWPs. :)
data.name: DaemonLab/OWP_Image_Viewer
Club of Programmers, IIT BHU Varanasi

data.message:
We have started a new series of tutorials which promote learning-via-coding! The series is called OWP (One Week Projects). The tutorials are aimed to develop small apps which can be made in approximately 1 week time while still being useful upto some extent. The first tutorial in this series is based on the Win32 API and develops a decent Paint Application for windows in just 6 steps. You can go through the state of the code at each commit and learn how the code progresses using the explanation provided in comments and also in readme. The tutorial can be found on github at https://github.com/DaemonLab/OWP_Paint_App.
The next tutorial will be using a cross platform GUI library. So be sure to watch our official account on github at https://github.com/DaemonLab/.
data.name: DaemonLab/OWP_Paint_App

data.message:
“Surprise is the greatest gift which life can grant us.” - Boris Pasternak

Are you ready for something challenging? Something adventurous?
FLUXUS - IIT Indore & Programming Club, IIT Indore present: the Surprise Language Programming Contest. Here, unlike a regular programming contest, you will only be able to use one language, which will be announced 15 mins before the contest. So be ready to compete, you might even learn a whole new language along the way!

The language will be one among following and will be announced 15 minutes before the contest at the event page.

Erlang
LOLCODE
Smalltalk
Clojure
Scala
Common Lisp (SBCL)
Rust
COBOL
Racket
Tcl
Whitespace

Prizes worth 12K!

Finally, don't forget to register at http://www.fluxus.in/registration/registration.php as Prizes are only applicable to users with a Fluxus-ID

data.message:
Thanks for making Code Bug 1.0 a success!
Solutions and results will be out soon!
Hope to see you all again at our next event!

“Just because you've counted all the trees doesn't mean you've seen the forest” – Anonymous.

Testing is a very important paradigm of Software Development. Without it, Codes are never complete. So, rather than keeping the conventional Coding Contest, this time Programming Club is back in action with its new Event - Code Bug 1.0. The Details of the Event are:
·         This will be a Testing contest where you will be given a set of problems and their codes and you need to find bugs present in the code.

·         Code of the problems will be in either C or C++.

·         This is a team event. A maximum of 2 participants can participate in a team.

·         Date, Time and Venue: 23rd February, 2014 Sunday 2:30 pm at Mess Basement, Silver Springs

·         Laptops are not allowed in the Contest. We will provide you the hard copy of problem set in which you need to modify the code.



We hope to see you there…
Regards,
Programming Club
 
For Details Contact:

Sai Nath: +91-9407406691
Krishna Chaitanya: +91-9407406691
Sreemathi Basker: +91-9993261335
Utkarsh Saxena: +91-9415552327
data.name: Code Bug 1.0
